fact: The first formal ambulance service began in Cincinnati in 1865.
Baron Dominique-Jean Larrey, Napoleon’s surgeon, created the first modern field ambulance in 1793.
The first civilian ambulance service in the U.S. was at Bellevue Hospital in NYC in 1869.
Early EMS systems were often run by funeral homes using hearses.
The white cross on a blue star, known as the Star of Life, was adopted by NHTSA in 1977.
Freedom House Ambulance (Pittsburgh, 1967) was one of the first to train EMTs in the U.S.
Before EMS, police and fire departments often handled medical emergencies without training.
Paramedics were first introduced into the U.S. healthcare system in the 1960s.
The term 'EMT' wasn't officially recognized until after the National EMS Systems Act of 1973.
The TV show Emergency! (1972–77) played a major role in public support for EMS development.
Vietnam War medic innovations helped shape modern civilian EMS techniques.
The 1966 'White Paper' report revealed serious deficiencies in U.S. emergency care.
The EMS profession emerged partly in response to rising motor vehicle accident deaths.
The first paramedic program started in Miami, Florida, in 1969.
Los Angeles County Fire pioneered integration of EMS with fire service.
The term 'paramedic' originally meant someone who works alongside a physician.
Helicopter EMS (HEMS) became more common in the 1970s for trauma patients.
EMS providers were not always allowed to start IVs until protocols expanded.
Defibrillators were first introduced to ambulances in the 1970s.
EMTs initially were trained in basic first aid before formal curriculum existed.
EMS became a recognized public safety field by the 1980s.
Some early EMT programs were just 20–30 hours long.
Prehospital trauma life support (PHTLS) revolutionized EMS trauma care.
Medical control evolved from phone calls with ER doctors to detailed protocols.
Military field medics have influenced nearly every major EMS innovation.
The Department of Transportation standardized EMT curriculum in the 1970s.
Early CPR training was provided by the Red Cross and military groups.
Paramedics were once required to be registered nurses in some areas.
Some states did not allow EMS to give oxygen until the late 1980s.
EMS has shifted from 'scoop and run' to 'stay and play' care models.
AEDs were not common in the field until the late 1990s.
EMS was not reimbursed by Medicare/Medicaid until the 1980s.
Early EMS calls were often dispatched by radio hobbyists or volunteers.
EMS was not originally considered part of the healthcare system.
The first NREMT exam was administered in 1971.
The EMS Agenda for the Future (1996) was a key planning document.
Public access defibrillation began in the 1990s.
Today’s EMS system is built on four pillars: response, transport, treatment, and documentation.
The first EMS helicopter used in the U.S. was at St. Anthony Hospital, Denver, in 1972.
EMS Week was established by President Ford in 1974.
The paramedic symbol (Star of Life) has six points, each representing a core EMS function.
911 was not a national standard until the 1980s.
EMS data registries began in the early 2000s to track performance.
EMT-B and EMT-P designations were simplified to EMT and Paramedic by the 2010s.
Some EMS agencies were originally volunteer fire brigades.
The first field intubations were highly controversial.
Training hours for paramedics now exceed 1,200 hours in most states.
EMS is now recognized as a vital component of homeland security and disaster response.
Many EMS systems today use tiered response with BLS and ALS units.
COVID-19 brought public attention and funding back to EMS roles.
NEMSIS is the national EMS data collection system established in the early 2000s.
The human brain has around 86 billion neurons.
The body contains enough iron to make a 3-inch nail.
The average adult takes about 20,000 breaths per day.
Your stomach gets a new lining every 3 to 4 days.
The liver performs over 500 functions in the body.
The surface area of the lungs is about the size of a tennis court.
You blink about 15–20 times per minute.
Your bones are 5x stronger than steel, ounce for ounce.
Blood travels about 12,000 miles a day in the human body.
Each kidney contains about 1 million filtering units called nephrons.
The small intestine is about 22 feet long.
Nerve impulses can travel up to 250 mph.
The heart beats around 100,000 times per day.
Skin is the body's largest organ.
The human nose can detect over 1 trillion scents.
Red blood cells live about 120 days.
Muscles make up about 40% of total body weight.
You produce 1 to 1.5 liters of saliva a day.
The average person has about 5 million hairs.
You lose about 600,000 skin cells every hour.
Your ears continue to grow throughout your life.
Bones are constantly being broken down and rebuilt.
The brain uses about 20% of the body’s total energy.
You have over 600 muscles in your body.
Your fingerprints are formed in the womb.
The tongue is made of 8 muscles.
Your pupils dilate in just 200 milliseconds.
A fetus develops fingerprints by 17 weeks.
The body has about 60,000 miles of blood vessels.
More than half your bones are in your hands and feet.
Hair grows faster in warm weather.
Your eyes can distinguish about 10 million different colors.
Adrenaline boosts energy and reduces pain temporarily.
The appendix may help maintain gut flora.
Goosebumps are a reaction to emotional or cold stimuli.
The average person has about 2.5 million sweat glands.
Brain cells can survive 5–10 minutes without oxygen.
The left lung is smaller to make room for the heart.
Your vocal cords can stretch over 1 inch during speech.
Tears contain natural painkillers.
The pancreas produces both insulin and digestive enzymes.
The body contains trillions of bacteria, mostly in the gut.
Men typically have more red blood cells than women.
The body maintains a temperature of ~98.6°F (37°C).
The cornea has no blood vessels—it gets oxygen from air.
The thyroid regulates metabolism and energy levels.
Your nails grow faster on your dominant hand.
The liver can regenerate even if partially removed.
Each person’s brain has a unique structure and folding pattern.
Babies have more bones than adults (around 300 vs. 206).
